ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Great course. If you're interested in: public health, gender studies, sexuality studies, anthropology, sociology, etc. take it!
This is a wonderful class. Prof. Reid is so kind and calm but very sharp and witty. I loved being in it and learned so much. Not a terrible workload either.
recommended, but reid isnt teaching it anymore
One of the easier classes Yale has to offer. 3 papers (5pgs each). One book per week. 1 class presentation about ANYTHING related to HIV.

Highly recommended. Graeme Reid is a great professor and this material is incredibly important to learn. I really hope that even though Professor Reid is leaving, Yale will find someone else to teach a course on this topic.
Take it if you're interested in the subject - the readings are always good, sometimes really really good. Graeme is also the best.

This class is a solid introduction to the most pressing issues around representation of and intervention in African HIV/AIDS crises. The readings are terrific and will get you thinking about these problems in a nuanced, intersectional way. Certainly take this class if you're a WGSS, African Studies, or Anthropology major, but this class might be even more important for you if you're into global health, international relations, or medicine.
Yes, take it--but only if laptops are no longer allowed in the seminar. It's a great exploration of the topic--thoughtful, not prescriptive.
